BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. In addition an appreciable danger of wet snow slides and avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, hard wind slabs formed in the last few days especially above approximately 2300 m. These are easy to recognise but in some cases prone to triggering. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2800 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, as well as on very steep southeast, south facing slopes.
Individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on very steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be mild. As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, rather small wind slabs formed. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 2200 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. In some localities increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, hard wind slabs formed in the last few days especially above approximately 2300 m. These are easy to recognise but in some cases prone to triggering. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Skiers can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones.

Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2800 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, as well as on very steep southeast, south facing slopes.
More gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on very steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be mild.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Since Wednesday numerous small and medium-sized avalanches occurred naturally. Naturally triggered avalanches and field observations confirm a sometimes precarious avalanche situation in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from northwesterly directions, extensive wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones. Avalanche prone locations are to be found on wind-loaded slopes above approximately 2400 m and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.

More gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes mostly small loose snow avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Friday: Evening: 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen.

The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow. This applies at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes:
The high temperatures gave rise to significant moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs and gliding snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was reduced. The danger of ground avalanches will already increase in the late morning. Wind slabs above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. Already in the early morning, a few, then as a consequence of warming during the day more, and in some cases even large, wet and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be a rapid increase in the danger of wet avalanches to level 3 (considerable).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist and wet avalanches are still possible. In addition the clearly visible wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From starting zones where no previous releases have taken place on rocky sunny slopes moist avalanches can as before reach fairly large size, caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep slopes below approximately 2600 m, and at the base of rock walls.
In the last few days clearly visible wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as in high Alpine regions. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
The hard wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like. The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
Naturally triggered avalanches and field observations indicate poor snowpack stability on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. The meteorological conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the near-surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist and wet avalanches are still possible. In addition the clearly visible wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day more small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2700 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
The older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. They are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2600 m. On very steep sunny slopes several small to medium-sized avalanches were observed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
The weather will be mild over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on weak layers.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area further warming to the high Alpine regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In particular in the south and at the base of rock walls medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will increase. Moist avalanches can occur naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in all aspects. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 1900 m.
On steep slopes more wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1900 m, especially at their margins. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes. In addition there is a danger of wet snow slides and avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released by people in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of warming during the day individual small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2500 m. On steep sunny slopes as well as at low and intermediate altitudes less snow than usual is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form on north and east facing slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are a little more prevalent and exist in all aspects. Avalanches can in some cases reach medium size.

More gliding avalanches are possible, even quite large ones, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes more small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen in particular in the north. Up to intermediate altitudes rain has fallen.

High altitudes and the high Alpine regions:
The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers at elevated altitudes. They are in some cases prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate altitudes: Early and late morning: The snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs and gliding snow represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
The weather will be mild in the regions exposed to the foehn wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of high temperatures, solar radiation and the moderate to strong northerly foehn wind, a treacherous avalanche situation will develop on Saturday. In addition the fresh and older wind slabs must be taken into account. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. In addition by the evening in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, further small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2700 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size during the last few days. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep sunny slopes. In high Alpine regions there will be only a slight increase in the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. In high Alpine regions a little snow is lying. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. The weather conditions will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack also at high altitude.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be mild over a wide area. Over a wide area continuous warming to the high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day individual mostly small moist and wet snow slides are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Moist snow slides are possible during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable. Early and late morning: The snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.
